In this study, the tunability of oxygen vacancies in bismuth molybdate was achieved using a simple solvothermal method assisted by iodine doping. Various characterizations were conducted to investigate the relationship between oxygen vacancy concentrations in bismuth molybdate and iodine doping. The introduction of ample oxygen vacancies through the doping of iodine significantly enhanced molecular oxygen activation, granting Bi2MoO6 high activity for the photocatalytic degradation of 2,4-DCP. Furthermore, the degradation of 2,4-DCP under visible light irradiation reached 78% completion within 180 min. The removal of 2,4-DCP by the I-BMO/PMS system was improved to 87% because of the crucial role of PMS in generating SO4 2- and inducing photogenerated electron synergism. The results of free radical trapping experiments were combined with these findings to propose a possible degradation mechanism for 2,4-DCP. This study provides a novel perspective on the photocatalytic degradation of organochlorine pesticides using Bi2MoO6. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Pesticide wastewater Photocatalysis Bismuth-based photocatalysis Mechanistic analysis Difficult-to-degrade micropollutants Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction Advances in modernizing agriculture have led to increased pesticide use in farming, creating a significant problem in treating pesticide-contaminated wastewater [31]. This wastewater contains dichlorophenol (DCP), a harmful chemical that can persist in the environment [66]. Improper management and release of DCP during industrial activities can lead to its buildup in soil, water, and air, posing serious environmental and human health risks [11]. Pesticide wastewater typically contains chemical oxygen demand (COD) levels ranging from 150 to 750 mg/L and biochemical oxygen demand (BOD) levels from 30 to 599 mg/L [22–71]. Numerous rivers and lakes have already surpassed these thresholds, posing significant risks to human health [30]. Therefore, it is crucial to research and implement effective methods to remove 2,4-DCP from water sources to maintain ecosystem balance [41–52]. Conventional methods for treating 2,4-dichlorophenol (2,4-DCP) wastewater include physical adsorption, biodegradation [46], and chemical treatment [21–67]. Physical treatment techniques may result in the leakage of large quantities of chlorophenols and other pollutants, leading to serious secondary pollution. To effectively remove chlorophenols from wastewater, precipitation, activated carbon adsorption, and reverse osmosis are commonly used [25]. However, these technologies only involve a separation process that transfers contaminants from one stage to another without complete breakdown or detoxification [24]. This may lead to secondary contamination and require subsequent treatment technologies. Moreover, these methods are relatively expensive to treat. As emission standards for pollutants become increasingly stringent, traditional technologies are struggling to meet these requirements [17]. Photocatalysis has become a popular area of research. Bismuth molybdate (Bi2MoO6) is a promising material due to its narrow bandgap, which allows for effective absorption and utilization of visible light [14–62]. Bismuth molybdate is an environmentally friendly and nontoxic material that aligns with the 'carbon reduction' policy. Its excellent photocatalytic performance and diverse applications make it a cost-effective and efficient choice. It has been widely used by scholars due to its green and non-polluting nature [1]. It has been demonstrated that the design of defective state catalysts is an effective means of improving the electronic structure of photocatalysts [48]. Among the various approaches, the introduction of oxygen vacancies represents an excellent way to enhance the catalytic effect, as it is capable of effectively capturing free electrons, accelerating the separation of carriers, and achieving the efficient activation of molecular oxygen. Frequently required reactive groups, such as hydroxyl radicals and superoxide radicals, exhibit higher oxidative properties than O2 [9–32]. Despite numerous pioneering studies on OVs construction, the catalytic differentiation resulting from concentration modulation is still in its infancy, offering avenues for further research. Therefore, developing a straightforward approach for introducing OVs is crucial for elucidating the activation of molecular oxygen by OVs [23–35]. Iodine, an elemental halogen, can significantly alter the bandgap width and energy level structure of semiconductor materials. Oxygen vacancies formed by iodine doping can improve the optical properties of semiconductor materials and broaden the photoresponse range, increasing the number of active sites [33–51]. To enhance the ring-opening ability for 2,4-DCP, this study added PMS as an activator to generate more active groups. The flat band potential of sulfate is higher than that of hydroxyl radical, which means that the reaction between sulfate and H2O/OH- can also form ·OH [34]. The I-BMO/PMS system efficiently catalyzed the degradation of 2,4-DCP [42–55]. To summarize, we prepared iodine-doped bismuth molybdate composite photocatalysts using a simple solvothermal method. We estimated their photocatalytic activity by measuring the degradation efficiency of 2,4-DCP. We reduced the effect of interfacial resistance by adjusting the pH value and forming oxygen vacancies through halogen element doping, which changed the crystal structure to (010). Free radical trapping experiments were used to determine the types of active groups and speculate the possible photocatalytic 2,4-DCP degradation mechanism under activated PMS conditions. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Chemicals Chemicals for the syntheses were purchased from specific suppliers. Bismuth nitrate, sodium molybdate, and sodium dodecyl sulfate (CTAB) were obtained from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co. Ammonia, potassium iodide, and anhydrous ethanol were sourced from Shuangshuang Chemical Co in Fujian, China. Permonosulfate (PMS) and the primary pollutant treated, 2,4-dichlorophenol, was acquired from McLean Biochemical Technology Co in Shanghai, China. These reagents were of analytical grade, and chemical solutions were prepared using deionized (DI) water with a purity of 18.2 MΩ (Nanopure water, Barnstead). 2.2 Preparation of iodine-doped bismuth molybdate photocatalysts (1) Preparation of Bi2MoO6 The synthesis of iodine-doped bismuth molybdate was carried out using an in situ hydrothermal method. The synthesis process was similar to the previous one, with minor modifications. CTAB was dispersed in 40 ml of deionized water, and a potassium iodide solution with varying molar ratios was added dropwise under continuous stirring using a magnetic stirrer until complete dissolution. Subsequently, the pH was adjusted to 10 to obtain an orange-yellow mixture. The color of the solution ranged from light to dark depending on the quantity of dopant, and the samples were labeled accordingly as I-BMO-0.02, I-BMO-0.03, I-BMO-0.04, and I-BMO-0.05. The four prepared samples were washed several times with deionized water and anhydrous ethanol and then dried in an oven at 60 °C for 24 h. (2) Preparation of I-Bi2MoO6 The preparation of iodine-doped bismuth molybdate was synthesized by an in situ hydrothermal method. The preparation was synthesized similarly as above with slight modifications. CTAB was dispersed into 40 ml of deionized water, and potassium iodide solution with different molar ratios was added drop by drop with continuous stirring under a magnetic stirrer until complete dissolution, and then the pH was adjusted to 10 to make the mixture appear orange-yellow, and the color of the solution varied from light to dark according to the amount of dopant, which was labeled as I-BMO-0.02, I-BMO-0.03, I-BMO-0.04, I-BMO-0.05 respectively. The four as-prepared samples were washed with DI water and anhydrous ethanol several times and dried at 60 °C for 24 h in an oven. 2.3 Photocatalytic activity measurements To evaluate the photocatalytic activity of our catalysts, we conducted an investigation focusing on the degradation of 2,4-dichlorophenol under xenon lamp irradiation simulating sunlight (300 W). We introduced a specific amount of photocatalyst into a 50 mL solution containing 20 mg/L of 2,4-DCP. The suspension was stirred in darkness for 30 min to establish adsorption equilibrium. Subsequently, we performed photocatalytic experiments under xenon lamp irradiation. To assess the remaining concentration of 2,4-DCP in the solution, we periodically removed aliquots from the suspension, centrifuged them to separate the photocatalyst particles, filtered them through 0.22 μm organic-phase filter membranes, and determined the concentration of 2,4-DCP in the supernatant spectrophotometrically using 4-aminoantipyrine colorimetry. Each experiment was replicated three times, and the average of these measurements was used for subsequent analysis. 2.4 Reactive species detection The active species that play an important role in photocatalytic performance were investigated by introducing trapping agents under the same conditions. Isopropanol (IPA), benzoquinone (BQ), and ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid (EDTA-2Na) were used as scavengers of hydroxyl radicals (·OH), superoxide radicals (·O2 -), and photogenerated (h+), respectively. 2.5 Characterization The morphology and lattice properties of the I-BMO photocatalysts were determined using field-emission scanning electron microscopy (SEM) (TESCAN, MIR A3, Czech Republic) and transmission electron microscope (TEM) (FEI Tecnai G2 F20). The structures and chemical statuses of the samples were determined by X-ray diffraction (XRD, BRUKER D8 ADVANCE) and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) (Thermo Fisher-Alpha Plus, USA), respectively. Photoluminescence (PL) emission spectra were used to investigate the recombination rate of electrons and holes by employing a Fluorescence spectrometer (HITACHI F-7100) under excitation at 325 nm. The light absorption was determined by ultraviolet-visible diffuse reflectance spectrum (UV–vis DRS) (Shimadzu UV3600 Plus). Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) and transient photocurrent (TPC) were conducted using an electrochemical workstation with a three-electrode system, where FTO glass, HgO, and platinum electrodes served as the working electrode, reference electrode, and counter electrode, respectively. The concentration of RhB was analyzed using a UV–vis spectrophotometer (UV-2102, UNICO, China). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Phase structure and morphology analysis of catalyst Scanning electron microscopy and laser particle size measurements were used to analyze the morphological structure and particle size distribution of bismuth molybdate [50–61]. Fig. 1 shows that the original morphological structure of the bismuth molybdate remains unchanged after iodine doping. After adjusting the pH value, the bismuth molybdate transforms from fragments to interlaced lamellae, increasing the number of contact sites and improving its photocatalytic activity. Furthermore, as iodine doping increased, the lamellar I-BMO agglomerated, as depicted in Fig. 1(e). This phenomenon is attributed to the catalyst's particle size falling within a specific range. When the particle size is small, the number of active sites on the catalyst is limited, resulting in poor reaction activity. Conversely, when the particle size increases, the number of active sites on the catalyst also increases, leading to improved reaction activity. However, if the particle size is too large, the number of newly formed active sites decreases, and the reactivity begins to decline, resulting in catalyst agglomeration. The composite I-BMO-0.03 with a doping ratio of 0.03% exhibits excellent dispersion and a wide diameter size distribution, indicating uniform interfacial connections between the two components. 3.2 XRD The crystal structures of the I-BMO photocatalysts were investigated using XRD [8–13]. The X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of various samples are depicted in Fig. 2 . The XRD patterns of BMO and I-BMO-X showed similarities and aligned with JCPDS#76-2388 (BMO). However, a weak diffraction peak for Bi at 26.6° emerged after heating the I-BMO reactor, suggesting that BMO transforms into Bi at high temperatures [60]. The main peak for I-BMO corresponds to metallic Bi (JCPDS #44-1246). The most prominent peak of BMO is observed at 28.0°, suggesting that a portion of BMO may have transformed into Bi. Additionally, the XRD pattern does not show any other peaks indicative of impurities. The diffraction peaks at 2θ = 28.3°, 32.6°, 47.2°, and 55.6° correspond to the (131), (200), (260), and (133) crystal planes of the γ-Bi2MoO6 phase, respectively [4]. This is consistent with the research conducted by Brijesh Kumar Shukla et al. [6], who also confirmed the existence of these crystal surfaces in Bi2MoO6. Importantly, there are no shifts in the diffraction peaks, and the similarity in peak shapes suggests the successful preparation of γ-Bi2MoO6. Furthermore, it was observed that the peak intensity slightly varied with an increase in KI addition during the synthesis process, indicating that excessive doping could result in a reduction in the crystallinity of the catalytic materials [2,3] 3.3 TEM and EDS Fig. 3 exhibits TEM, HRTEM, and EDS images of the I-BMO composite, revealing successful composite formation with an interlaced lamellar structure. TEM and HRTEM analyses show clear potassium iodide lattice streaks in I-BMO, indicating high crystallinity. A lattice spacing of 0.332 nm corresponds to the (001) and (010) crystal planes of Bi2MoO6, consistent with XRD findings, suggesting the presence of oxygen vacancies. EDS characterization confirms successful material synthesis, showing strong peaks of Bi, Mo, and I elements, indicating successful preparation. 3.4 XPS analysis The surface chemistry and elemental valence states of I-BMO were analyzed by XPS, and the results are shown in Fig. 4 . Notably, peaks of iodine appear in the BMO-0.03 sample, indicating that iodine was successfully introduced into the crystal structure of bismuth molybdate [7]. From the XPS spectra, four peaks corresponding to Bi 4f, I 3d, Mo 3d, and O 1 s were observed in the composite catalyst, confirming the successful synthesis of the I-BMO composite photocatalyst. The binding energy of C 1 s (284.6 e V) was used for calibration prior to analysis. The XPS spectrum of the composite catalyst I-BMO-0.03 shows that Bi4f7/2 and Bi4f5/2 correspond to peaks at 158.78 and 164.07 eV, respectively [59–65], and the binding energy between the two peaks is approximately 5.3 eV, indicating that the valence state of elemental bismuth is +3. The binding energy of Bi3+ increases by 0.2 eV compared to that of the BMO samples (158.9 eV and 164.2 eV), suggesting that there may be oxygen vacancies on the BMO-0.03 surface [54–64]. Furthermore, from the results of the Bi 4f spectra of I-BMO-0.03, low-valent bismuth elements were detected on the surface of the material, which may result from the escape of lattice oxygen and the appearance of oxygen defects, leading to the reduction of bismuth atoms [12]. The binding energy 235.63 eV and 232.50 eV were attributed to Mo3d5/2 and Mo3d3/2, respectively, and the binding energy 233.92 eV was for the low oxidation state of Mo (V), suggesting the formation of oxygen vacancies on the surface of the catalyst. The binding energy difference of element I indicates a strong electron transfer and interaction between BizMoO6 and BixOxI. 3.5 Optical absorption and electrochemical characteristics The PL emission spectra are presented in Fig. 5 (c). Compared to its base catalyst, Bi2MoO6, as well as other doped quantities of the composite, the fluorescence intensity of iodine-doped I-BMO-0.03 is lower. It is worth mentioning that fluorescence analysis is used to evaluate the extent of recombination between photogenerated electrons and holes, where a higher recombination rate translates to a more prominent spectral peak. Based on our findings, I-BMO-0.03 demonstrates enhanced photogenerated electron-hole separation and a reduced recombination rate, thus further confirming its outstanding photocatalytic capabilities [19]. For photocatalysis, the hole transfer ability and the separation efficiency of electrons are the key factors affecting photoactivity [58]. Therefore, in the next experiments, we performed photocurrent cycling experiments on Bi2MoO6 and I-BMO-0.03. As shown in Fig 5(b), the photocurrent intensity of I-BMO-0.03 is higher than that of the base catalyst Bi2MoO6, which indicates that the BMO doped with 0.03 has a strong carrier transfer ability and separation efficiency. To further verify the photoelectron separation efficiency of the composite, electrochemical impedance spectroscopy was used to analyze its photogenerated charge separation ability and transmission properties [39–72]. As can be seen from the figure, the impedance spectral radius of I-BMO-0.03 is the smallest, which is lower than the semicircular radius of the substrate material, which suggests that oxygen vacancies introduced by iodine doping largely contribute to the photogenerated electron-hole separation rate. The results of the EIS and PL tests were consistent, demonstrating that the I-BMO-0.03 photocatalysis has a good carrier separation effect and excellent photocatalytic performance. The light absorption properties of the prepared composites were investigated by measuring the UV–Vis diffuse reflectance spectra of the samples in Fig. 6 [16–57]. The light absorption property is a key factor in determining the performance of catalytic materials, and the absorption boundary between 400 and 500 nm indicates that the material has the ability of light absorption, which is more favorable to the photocatalytic reaction. At the same time, there is no significant change in the absorption position of the composite material compared with the single catalytic material BMO. For semiconductor materials, when calculating the band gap energy, it can be calculated based on the relationship between the optical band gap and the absorption coefficient: (1) α hv = A ( h v − E g ) n / 2 Where A, h, v, Eg, and α represent the proportional constant, Planck constant, optical frequency, band gap, and optical absorption coefficient. Bi₂MoO₆ is a direct semiconductor with an n-value of 1. The calculated bandgap of this material is approximately 2.5 eV. Furthermore, the data from different control groups indicated that the difference in bandgap is negligible, suggesting that the Vo-BMO did not alter the forbidden bandwidth of the material and that the light-absorbing ability is similar in this study. 3.6 Influence factor For experimental analysis, several typical factors that affect the photocatalytic degradation process were selected, which included the photocatalyst dosage, 2,4-DCP concentration, pH, and other variables that impact the photocatalytic degradation efficiency [47–69]. By adjusting various conditions of these influencing factors, the optimal experimental conditions were established. 3.6.1 Dosage of I-BMO The utilization of a catalyst plays a pivotal role in influencing the number of active sites, as illustrated in Fig. 7 (a). Following the introduction of 30 mg of catalyst I-BMO-0.03 over a period of 180 min, the degradation efficiency of 2,4-DCP reached approximately 87%. Augmenting the quantity of catalyst notably enhanced the catalytic efficacy by augmenting the count of active sites and broadening the effective specific surface area that interfaces with the pollutant. Nevertheless, surpassing a certain threshold in dosage led to a decline in the degradation of 2,4-dichlorophenol. This decline is presumed to be attributed to an escalation in solution opacity induced by an excessive aggregation of photocatalysts in aqueous settings. This opacity hinders the transmission of solar light, thereby impacting the photo-reaction capability of specific active sites and diminishing the photodegradation process. 3.6.2 Concentration of 2,4-DCP Fig. 7(b) displays the degradation efficiencies at various initial concentrations. As is typical in most papers, the degradation ability of the I-BMO/PMS system improves with increasing concentrations of the pollutant 2,4-DCP. This is due to the larger contact surface of its photocatalyst resulting from higher pollutant content, leading to a better degradation effect. Furthermore, increasing the concentration of 2,4-DCP from 20 mg/L to 40 mg/L did not significantly affect the I-BMO-0.03 catalyst. This indicates the catalyst's effectiveness in degrading the pollutant. The photocatalytic degradation time of the system was 180 min when 30 mg of the catalyst was used at the same pH value, resulting in an 87% degradation efficiency. However, the photocatalytic degradation performance decreased slightly with the continuous increase in 2,4-DCP concentration. This decrease may be attributed to the production of secondary metabolites, which consumed some of the active groups (·OH and H+) as the 2,4-DCP concentration increased. This reduction in active groups decreased the redox capacity of 2,4-DCP. 3.6.3 pH The impact of H+ and ·OH on substance charge density in aqueous environments significantly affects adsorption and photocatalytic degradation. Fig. 8 (a) depicts catalytic degradation performance at various initial pH values (4–9). Experimental results show that I-BMO degrades over 80% of 2,4-DCP in acidic conditions (pH<7). Without pH adjustment, 87% degradation of 2,4-DCP occurred within 180 min at a 20 mg/L pollutant concentration in a 50 mL solution, using a catalyst dose of 30 mg and a PMS dose of 1 mmol/L. Furthermore, degradation of 2,4-DCP was observed under alkaline conditions (pH>7), achieving only 78% degradation. This difference was due to variations in the surface charge of the photocatalyst and 2,4-DCP depending on pH levels. The optimal adsorption performance of the surface charge was attained under neutral conditions. 3.6.4 Dopant quantity Previous studies and characterization techniques have established that varying iodine doping levels in I-BMO significantly impact the degradation of 2,4-DCP. Fig. 8(b) illustrates the photocatalytic activity, revealing a correlation between the degradation efficiency of 2,4-DCP and the amount of doping. The modified BMO exhibits preservation of its original structural features while significantly augmenting its absorption capabilities within the visible light spectrum. Additionally, the introduction of oxygen vacancies significantly boosts the chemical adsorption of oxygen on the catalytic material, thereby enhancing its capacity to activate molecular oxygen under visible light. Experimental results indicate that 3% iodine doping is the most effective for degrading 2,4-DCP under neutral pH conditions, with a pollutant concentration of 20 mg/L and a catalyst amount of 30 mg. Notably, at lower dosages, the degradation efficiency remains below 80%. This observation can be attributed to a decrease in the generation of oxygen vacancies as the doping amount increases, leading to a weakened activation of molecular oxygen and a subsequent reduction in catalytic activity. Consequently, taking into account the catalytic effect and other pertinent factors, I-BMO-0.03 with 3% iodine doping was selected as the optimal photocatalyst for the photodegradation experiments. 3.6.5 PMS doping amount To investigate the role of PMS further, we explored the effect of different PMS concentrations on the degradation of 2,4-DCP. The results are shown in Fig. 9 , where the degradation efficiency and reaction rate of 2,4-DCP increased with the increase of the amount of PMS from 1 mM/L to 15 mM/L. However, continuously increasing the amount of PMS did not significantly improve the 2,4-DCP degradation efficiency. This can be explained by the fact that the oxidative substances produced in the I-BMO/PMS system had already maximised the decomposition of 2,4-DCP when the PMS dosage reached 15 mM/L. Therefore, simply increasing the amount of PMS did not consistently improve the degradation efficiency of 2,4-DCP. However, as the initial PMS dosage was increased, it increased the contact between PMS and the catalyst, which produced more oxidizing substances in the early stages of the reaction, thus increasing the initial stage reaction rate. In consideration of economic factors and the relatively high 2,4-DCP removal efficiency, the PMS concentration of 15 mM/L was selected for the next study. 3.7 Photocatalytic performance The degradation performance of the I-BMO-0.03 composite catalysts was evaluated through photocatalytic degradation of 2,4-DCP under xenon lamp irradiation. As can be observed in Fig. 10 , the concentration of 2,4-DCP decreased by only 12% after 180 min when no catalyst was present. This indicates that during the photodegradation of 2,4-DCP, there is indeed a weak and negligible photosensitization phenomenon. The I-BMO composites exhibited higher catalytic activity than the pristine BMO, indicating that iodine doping creates more oxygen vacancies, which enhance the separation of electron-hole pairs and improve photocatalytic performance. However, with increasing iodine doping, I-BMO-0.05 exhibited a lower degradation rate. This is probably because, as the concentration of oxygen vacancies increases, the degradation activity first enhances and then plateaus. Once excessive oxygen vacancies are generated on the material's surface, the available active sites and adsorption space become limited [15–18]. This limitation prevents further enhancement of the material's photocatalytic activity, meaning that continued increases in oxygen vacancy concentration do not result in further photocatalytic activity enhancement. Photocatalytic degradation is usually represented by a pseudo-first-order kinetic model, calculated as follows, and the results are shown in Fig. 9. (2) ln C t C 0 = K t Ct and C0 represent the pollutant concentrations at time 0 and t, respectively; K denotes the apparent rate constant (min-1). The first-order kinetics of different photocatalysts are shown in Fig. 10(b). The correlation coefficients (R2) were all greater than 0.95. Meanwhile, the highest K value was obtained for the I-BMO-0.03 sample, which indicates that the appropriate molar ratio of Bi and I elements can greatly improve photocatalytic activity. Therefore, we selected I-BMO-0.03 as the best photocatalyst for further degradation experiments. 3.8 Stability test Fig. 11 (a) presents the results of the cycling experiments conducted to assess the reproducibility of the photocatalytic materials. The photocatalytic degradation efficiency of the I-BMO-0.03 photocatalyst exhibited a slight decline with increasing cycle counts during the 10-cycle tests. However, this decline is likely due to sample losses and operational inaccuracies encountered during the photocatalyst recycling process. The removal efficiency of 2,4-DCP remained high at 80% even in the 10th cycle experiment, confirming the excellent photochemical and mechanical stability of the I-BMO-0.03 photocatalyst developed in this study. Its impressive performance and demonstrated stability hold great promise for future practical applications in water treatment [68–70]. Table 1 compares our study with others, evaluating various aspects such as preparation methods, cost, and environmental friendliness. The I-BMO material demonstrates an excellent cost-performance ratio and holds significant implications for future work. 3.9 Degradation pathways and possible photocatalytic mechanisms 3.9.1 Free radical capture experiments To confirm the photocatalytic degradation mechanism of I-BMO-0.03, the degradation of the target pollutant 2,4-DCP by the I-BMO-0.03+PMS system under different burst conditions was investigated in this experiment. Isopropanol (IPA), benzoquinone (BQ), and disodium ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid (EDTA-2Na) were used as ·OH, ·O2 - and pore trapping agents, respectively [43]. The results are presented in Fig. 11(b). Without any added capture agent, the I-BMO-0.03 photocatalyst achieved an 87.6% degradation efficiency for 2,4-DCP under specific conditions. When a certain amount of IPA was added, the degradation rate decreased to 61.7%. The addition of EDTA-2Na further reduced the degradation rate to 54.2%. Both trapping agents had a significant inhibitory effect on the degradation of 2,4-DCP. Notably, when BQ was added, the degradation rate decreased to 37.6%. These results indicate that IPA and EDTA-2Na trapping agents have significant inhibitory effects on their photocatalytic activities. ·OH and h+ play a critical role in the photocatalytic reaction, suggesting that these radicals are the primary active groups involved in the I-BMO generation process. OV formation was also confirmed by EPR measurements(Fig. 11c). 3.9.2 Valence band guide position calculation and mechanism analysis To gain insight into the photocatalytic mechanism of the I-Bi2MoO6/PMS system, we confidently calculated the valence and conduction band positions of the photocatalysts. (3) E CB = X − Ee − 0 . 5 E g (4) E vb = E CB + E g (5) X = [ x ( A ) α x ( A ) bx ( c ) c ] 1 / a + b + c (6) X ( A ) = EIE + EEA Ee is a fixed value of 4.5 eV representing the electron free energy, ECB and Eg are the conduction band (CB) position and the forbidden bandwidth of the material. In addition, χ refers to the electronegativity of the semiconductor, where a, b, and c are the respective atomic numbers. x(A) is represented by the square root of the ionization energy and the electron affinity energy, which are explained in detail in the relevant literature. From the calculations, we conclude that the conduction band valence band positions (ECB/EVB) of Bi2MoO6 are −0.58eV/1.97 eV. To verify the photocatalytic degradation of 2,4-dichlorophenol by the I-BMO/PMS system, potential intermediates were analyzed using the variation in m/z of the molecular ion peak [M + H]+ employing liquid chromatography-mass spectrometry (LC-MS). The results are presented in Fig. 14. Initially, 2,4-dichlorophenol was attacked by reactive oxygen species (ROS) such as ·OH, ·O2 -, and ·SO4 -, and converted to 4-chlorophenol or 2-chlorophenol through hydroxylation, a dechlorination process. When the m/z 94 fragment appears, the remaining chlorine is also removed, producing the intermediate phenol. Subsequently, further hydroxylation produces hydroquinone, a volatile compound. ·OH radicals attack the adjacent hydroxyl group on the benzene ring via electrophilic addition reactions. This attack causes ring-opening oxidation, C = C cleavage, and oxidation to small organic molecules like 2,4-hexadecenoic acid. Finally, with prolonged photocatalytic degradation, all intermediates are fully mineralized to CO2 and H2O. It is confirmed that these intermediates are small quantities of nontoxic or low-toxicity, low-activity, and chemically unstable organic compounds. Mineralisation is also confirmed by the results of the TOC as shown in Fig. 12 . 3.9.3 Toxicity test To assess the toxicity of 2,4-DCP and its intermediates, the structural characteristics of the compounds were used to analyze and predict the toxicity of the substance in the water column to fish, daphnia, and green algae. The acute and chronic toxicity of 2,4-DCP and intermediates were predicted and analyzed by the ECOSAR program in EPIWEB software. As shown in Fig. 13 , the LC50 value represents the 50% lethal concentration to fish and aquatic invertebrates, the EC50 value represents the 50% effect concentration to algae, and the ChV indicates chronic toxicity to fish, marine invertebrates, and algae. The results suggest that most of the physiological toxicity of the intermediates is lower than that of 2,4-DCP (larger values in the table represent lower toxicity). Overall, the I-BMO/PMS system performs excellently and degrades 2,4-DCP without generating more toxic stimulation products than the parent substance. This work is remarkable for its practical applications and development prospects. 3.9.4 Possible photocatalytic mechanism Based on the available characterization analysis, a possible degradation mechanism is proposed to explain the photocatalytic performance study of the I-BMO/PMS system for the removal of 2,4-DCP. As in Fig. 14 , firstly, under the irradiation of visible light. Light-induced generation of photogenerated electrons and hole separation caused Bi2MoO6 to be excited. Combining the UV-vis DRS and photocurrent properties, the valence and conduction bands of the synthesized I-BMO were calculated to be in the appropriate positions, respectively. The CB and VB of BMO were not significantly shifted under iodine doping, the oxygen vacancies generated on the surface promoted photogenerated electron-hole separation and enhanced the catalytic activity by trapping electrons [5–38]. (7) eCB -+O2→·O2 - (8) eCB -+HSO5 -→SO4 -+OH- (9) hVB ++H2O→H++·OH (10) SO4· -+H2O→H++·OH+SO4 2- (11) SO4· -+OH-→·OH+SO4 2- (12) hVB ++2,4-DCP→Products (13) (SO4· -, ·OH, hVB +) +2,4-DCP→Products Bi2MoO6 has a CB potential that is more negative than the redox potential of O2/·O2 -, which facilitates the transfer of electrons to produce ·O2 -. The generation of ·SO4 - by PMS plays a crucial role in inducing the synergistic effect by producing photogenerated electrons. The generation of ·O2 - involves two mechanisms. Bi2MoO6′s electron-hole (h+) oxidizes OH- to produce ·OH due to its positive VB potential compared to the redox potentials of OH-/·OH and H2O/·OH. Additionally, ·OH can be generated from the reaction between ·SO4 - and H2O/OH-, as the redox potential of ·SO4 -/SO4 2- (ranging from 2.5 to 3.1 eV, relative to NHE) exceeds that of hydroxyl radicals. In conclusion, the degradation of 2,4-DCP in the I-Bi2MoO6/PMS system is unequivocally attributed to the generation of highly reactive radicals, including ·SO4 -, ·OH, ·O2 -, and h+, and their synergistic effect on the reaction. 4 Conclusion The experiment produced I-BMO-0.03, which demonstrated excellent degradation performance, achieving an 87.66% degradation efficiency of 2,4-DCP in 180 min. Furthermore, it exhibited good photodegradation ability for concentrations of 2,4-DCP below 40 mg/L, with the best degradation effect observed under neutral conditions without altering the original pH value. This is highly beneficial for water treatment as it eliminates the need to adjust the pH value of the water body to meet environmental protection standards, thus avoiding secondary pollution. The photocatalyst prepared in this experiment demonstrates clear advantages in dosage, degradation effect, and reaction time compared to related literature. Moreover, I-BMO generates oxygen vacancies that increase the production of hydroxyl radicals (·OH) and holes, enhancing the activation of PMS and improving the degradation efficiency of 2,4-DCP through dechlorination and ring-breaking. The I-BMO/PMS system exhibits remarkable resilience to environmental disturbances, is compatible with diverse water bodies, and holds immense potential for practical applications. This work efficiently regulates the generation of reactive oxygen species (ROS) during PMS activation and reveals the underlying mechanism. Therefore, it provides a highly cost-effective solution for solving the problem of chlorophenol residue. There is a continued necessity for in-depth investigation in specific research domains, particularly the utilization of advanced primary representation methods and the incorporation of theoretical computations like Density Functional Theory (DFT) to gain a more profound understanding of photodegradation mechanisms. This methodology seeks to clarify the degradation pathways and the evolution of intermediate products, thus enabling more precise control over degradation processes. coredata.dc:description: In this study, the tunability of oxygen vacancies in bismuth molybdate was achieved using a simple solvothermal method assisted by iodine doping. Various characterizations were conducted to investigate the relationship between oxygen vacancy concentrations in bismuth molybdate and iodine doping. The introduction of ample oxygen vacancies through the doping of iodine significantly enhanced molecular oxygen activation, granting Bi2MoO6 high activity for the photocatalytic degradation of 2,4-DCP. Furthermore, the degradation of 2,4-DCP under visible light irradiation reached 78% completion within 180 min. The removal of 2,4-DCP by the I-BMO/PMS system was improved to 87% because of the crucial role of PMS in generating SO4 2- and inducing photogenerated electron synergism. The results of free radical trapping experiments were combined with these findings to propose a possible degradation mechanism for 2,4-DCP. This study provides a novel perspective on the photocatalytic degradation of organochlorine pesticides using Bi2MoO6.
